Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 44471  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
November 2011 
 
 
 
Federated States of Micronesia: Strengthening 
Infrastructure Planning and Implementation  
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DTCI  –  Department of Transportation, Communications and Infrastructure 
  FSM  –  Federated States of Micronesia 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
       
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (energy; water supply and other municipal 
infrastructure and services; public sector management; 
transport and information and communication technology) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development, 
organizational development); economic growth (promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling business environment); and 
governance (economic and financial governance, public 
administration);  
Location impact  –  Rural (medium), urban (high), national (high), regional (low) 
Partnership  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
  
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  R. Wihtol, Pacific Department (PARD) 
Director  A. Iffland, Urban, Social Development and Public Management Division, 
PARD 
   
Team leader  S. Pedersen, Principal Public Management Specialist, PARD 
Team member  S. Blaik, Senior Urban Development Specialist, PARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Basic infrastructure systems, such as power, transportation, and communications, are 
essential for the economic development of a country. The proposed technical assistance (TA) 
will  (i) support state  utilities  within  the  Federated  States  of  Micronesia  (FSM)  in  executing 
infrastructure projects more effectively by having an agreed upon approach to systems and 
procedures for project planning, design, and management across the country; and (ii) build 
capacity in the Department of Transportation, Communications and Infrastructure (DTCI) to 
plan, design, and oversee project execution. The TA was included in the country operations and 
business  plan,  2011–2013  at  the  request  of  the  national  and  state  governments.1 The 
government  was  consulted  and  has  agreed  with  the  proposed  impact,  output,  outcomes, 
implementation arrangements, cost and financing arrangements, and terms of reference for 
consultants.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  FSM  exhibits  the  characteristics  of  a  fragile  state.  Capacity  for  development 
management  is  limited,  governance  systems  are  undeveloped,  and  performance  of  past 
projects was not satisfactory. While the government is committed to its Strategic Development 
Plan,  2004–2023,  limited  capacity  within  the  national  and  state  governments  to  plan  and 
manage the implementation of infrastructure projects is hindering development.3  
 
3.  Economic growth in the FSM in the medium term is estimated at 0.6%. Private sector 
growth is sluggish. Because the FSM lacks effective power, transportation, and communication 
infrastructure, foreign investors’ commitment to the country is weak. Better project management 
would support timely execution of projects and hence would meet the conditions for drawdown 
of infrastructure grants under the Compact of Free Association.4 
 
4.  The 2004–2023 Infrastructure Development Plan highlighted the need for a high level of 
program  management,  technical  skills,  and  financial  and  reporting  skills  for  the  detailed 
planning,  technical  analysis,  resource  mobilization,  financial  management,  and  reporting 
systems  that  would  be  required.  However,  limited  needs  assessments  and  little  capacity 
building at any level has been undertaken. 
 
5.  Progress is hampered, in particular, by undefined procurement processes and building 
standards, and disagreement within the FSM about project management processes (as well as 
unresolved land issues, inadequate long-term planning, lack of funding for maintenance, and 
lack of technical capacity).5 These issues are compounded by unclear legal and regulatory 
                                                
1  Asian Development Bank. 2010. Country Operations Business Plan: Federated States of Micronesia, 2011–2013. 
Manila. The FSM Constitution established three levels of government: (i) national, (ii) state, and (iii) municipal. The 
national government’s powers are expressly delegated and provide for matters of foreign affairs and defense, 
taxation, regulation of banking, and coordination of foreign assistance. State governments have exclusive powers 
to deal with local issues and all residual powers. Both national and state governments may (i) appropriate public 
funds; (ii) borrow money on the public credit; and (iii) establish systems of social security and public welfare.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 August 2011. 
3  Government of the Federated States of Micronesia. 2004. Strategic Development Plan, 2004–2023: Achieving 
Economic Growth and Self-Reliance. http://www.mra.fm/pdfs/news_StrategicPlan.pdf 
4  IMF. 2010. Article IV Consultation Mission with FSM Concluding Statement. Washington, DC. The Compact of 
Free Association between the governments of the United States and the FSM, signed in 1982 and renewed in 
2003 for 20 years, provides for US economic assistance to and defense of the FSM in exchange for US defense 
and operating rights, including denial of access to FSM territory by other nations and other agreements. 
5  Government of the United States. 2009. Federated States of Micronesia Fiscal Year 2008 Economic Review. 
Washington, DC.

2   
frameworks, the loose nature of the federal constitution of the states of Micronesia, and a 
tenuous sense of nationhood across the four states.  
 
6.  DTCI is the executing agency for almost all government infrastructure projects, including 
those funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). In the absence of a common project 
management system, processes, and basic standards between DTCI and the state utilities (as 
implementing  agencies  for  many  infrastructure  projects),  projects  cannot  be  implemented 
effectively. However, the state utilities are accountable to the state governments—not to the 
national government.6 With regard to proper project implementation, DTCI can only negotiate,  
persuade, and influence the state utilities.  
 
7.  However, DTCI has implemented a number of infrastructure projects at the request of 
state governments, in recognition of the state’s capacity constraints. In addition to having an 
oversight role for almost all infrastructure projects, DTCI also provides capacity support to the 
state implementing agencies.  
 
8.  ADB’s project completion reports identify procurement and project management issues 
as  causes  of  project  implementation  delays  and  unsatisfactory  outcomes.7 The  review  of 
governance and capacity building gaps in DTCI in 2010 found four main constraints on effective 
project implementation in its infrastructure division:8 
 
(i)  The  overall  capacity  of  the  infrastructure  division  is  weak,  particularly  in 
infrastructure  design,  project  management,  asset  management,  financial 
management,  procurement,  and  risk  management.  The  division  has  specific 
skills gaps in asset planning and capital works programming, and has only one 
qualified civil engineer.  
(ii)  Processes relating to project design and delivery, management of consultant 
procurement,  and  risk  management  are  not  consistently  defined,  applied,  or 
understood within the divisions of DTCI. Consequently, DTCI’s ability to influence 
the state utilities in implementing proper processes is very weak.  
(iii)  State  utilities,  as  a  consequence,  do  not  define,  apply,  or  understand  the 
processes. The ability of DTCI to plan and oversee infrastructure implementation 
is  severely  limited  because  project  definition and  costing  are  undertaken  by 
states  and  then  approved  by  the  National  Office  of  Statistics,  Budget  and 
Economic  Management,  Overseas  Development  Assistance  and  Compact 
Management and the Joint Economic Management Committee, and the budget is 
appropriated before assessment, review, and tendering by DTCI.  
(iv)  Governance issues arise at project inception through indecisive and risk-averse 
management, unclear and uncoordinated project description and design, and 
lack  of  project  ownership,  compounded  by  the  reluctance  of  DTCI  staff  to 
properly manage consultant project managers. 
 
9.  The absence of agreed systems and processes for planning, designing, and managing 
projects and the limited capacity of DTCI constrain effective project implementation in the FSM. 
 
                                                
6  Because the project management unit within DTCI implements Compact infrastructure grant projects, DTCI does 
wield some influence during implementation, but not in the selection of projects. 
7  ADB. 2002. Completion Report: Fisheries Development Project in the Federated States of Micronesia. Manila; 
ADB. 2010. Completion Report: Basic Social Services Project in the Federated States of Micronesia. Manila; ADB. 
2010. Completion Report: Private Sector Development Program in the Federated States of Micronesia. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Governance and Capacity Development Initiative (Phase 2). Manila.

3 
10.  The TA is aligned with (i) ADB's Strategy 2020, which defines infrastructure as a core 
area  of  operations;9 (ii) ADB’s  Pacific  Approach,  2010–2014,  which  addresses the  lack  of 
institutional and human capacity development and skilled and qualified labor within the fragile 
states of the Pacific;10 and (iii) ADB’s Integrating Capacity Development into Country Programs 
and Operations: Medium-Term Framework and Action Plan, 2007–2010.11  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  that  states  receive  adequate  support  to  execute 
infrastructure investment projects. The outcome will be that DTCI will have improved capacity to 
plan and oversee the execution of infrastructure projects.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will support the delivery of two outputs: (i) systems and procedures for project 
planning, design, and management agreed upon by DTCI and state utilities; and (ii) DTCI staff 
resources having the knowledge and skills in selected areas to plan, design, and oversee 
project execution. 
 
13.  Output 1─Systems and procedures for project planning, design, and management. 
Project  planning,  design  and  management  frameworks,  systems,  and  procedures  for 
infrastructure  investments  will  be  reviewed,  updated,  and/or  developed  with  DTCI  in 
consultation with the state utilities of Yap, Pohnpei, Kosrae, and Chuuk. This includes manuals 
on (i) planning of civil works, (ii) contracting of civil works, and (iii) management and supervision 
of  civil  works.  Procedures  for  coordinating  DTCI  and  state  utilities  in  planning,  design, 
implementation, and supervision of infrastructure investments will be developed. A contract 
procedures manual will be designed with DTCI and the four state utilities.  
 
14.  A document management and a management information system will be designed and 
implemented to facilitate organizational efficiency  within DTCI. These systems will also  be 
accessible by the state utilities. The need for further procedures manuals will be assessed, and 
manuals produced, as required. 
 
15.  Agreement between DTCI and state utilities on the proposed project planning, design, 
and  management  system  design  and  implementation  arrangements  will  be  essential. 
Implementation  of the agreed  upon  approach within  DTCI  will  include  ongoing monitoring, 
assessment, and review throughout the term of the TA.  
 
16.  Output 2─DTCI staff knowledge and skills improvement. An in-depth assessment of 
the capacity of DTCI staff and long-term contractors to plan, design, implement, and supervise 
infrastructure  projects  will  be  carried  out.  This  will  form  the  basis  for  tailored  capacity 
development programs for each division of DTCI. It will include formal and nonformal training.   
                                                
9  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
10  ADB. 2009. ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2010–2014. Manila. 
11  ADB. 2007. Integrating Capacity Development into Country Programs and Operations: Medium-Term Framework 
and Action Plan. Manila.

4   
Classroom training will be complemented by on-the-job training, where trainees will participate 
in procurement activities, contract administration, and project supervision.   
 
17.  The technical training programs will cover (i) introduction to infrastructure design, (ii) 
project management, (iii) asset management, (iv) financial management, (v) procurement, (vi) 
contract  administration,  and  (vii)  risk  management.  Climate  change  adaptation  will  be  an 
integrated part of all technical courses. The design of the capacity development program will be 
based on a modular approach, and training manuals will be produced for all subjects. Train-the-
trainer programs will be undertaken to create a permanent capacity within DTCI to train new 
staff. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The Government of FSM has requested ADB to finance $700,000 equivalent. The TA 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by 
ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation; 
access to telephone, facsimile, and internet facilities at the office of the DTCI; and other in-kind 
contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency, and DTCI will be the implementing agency. The TA 
will require 25 person-months of international consultants: (i) an institutional strengthening and 
development  specialist  (17  person-months);  (ii)  an  infrastructure  management  capacity 
specialist (5 person-months); and (iii) a capacity development expert (3 person-months). A 
national consultant with capacity development expertise will be hired for 12 person-months. All 
consultants will be hired on an individual basis, and all consulting services will be rendered 
intermittently.12 Consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time.) All procurement will be done in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented 
over 3 years starting on 1 December 2011 and ending on 30 November 2014.  
 
20.  A steering committee comprising senior management and change champions within 
DTCI and the four state utilities will be established within 1 month of approval of the TA. The 
steering  committee  will  provide  guidance  and  direction  for  TA  activities  to  ensure  (i) 
sustainability of outputs and outcomes, and (ii) that the TA activities are inclusive and engage a 
consultative and collaborative process. An inception workshop will be organized to discuss 
preliminary findings and issues with key stakeholders. A clear and coherent communication 
structure and monitoring and evaluation process will be designed and implemented to support 
the  steering  committee.  The  steering  committee  will  receive  quarterly  progress  reports, 
particularly on the change management process and the capacity development program.   
   
                                                
12  The most appropriate consultants are likely to be hired as individuals, as only a small number of consultants is 
required, and the selection criteria specify a combination of technical skills and North Pacific experience.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of the Federated States of Micronesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Strengthening Infrastructure Planning and Implementation, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3    
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  institutional  strengthening  support  and 
capacity  building  to  the  Department  of  Transportation,  Communications  and  Infrastructure 
(DTCI), the government institution in the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) responsible for 
project  implementation  and  management,  thus  contributing  to  better  state  infrastructure 
execution.  
 
A.  Scope of Work  
 
2.    The TA will provide about 25 person-months of international consulting services and 
12 person-months of national consulting services intermittently over 3 years. Under the TA, 
DTCI and state utilities will agree upon a system and process for project planning, design, and 
management. In addition, the TA will build DTCI staff capacity to plan, design, and oversee 
infrastructure program execution. The TA will build upon previous initiatives to develop an 
organizational framework for DTCI and will also identify links to capacity development outside 
the parameters of the TA. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference  
 
1.  Institutional Strengthening and Development Specialist (international, 
17 person-months intermittent over 24 months)  
 
3.  The  specialist  will  have  extensive  experience  in  institutional  strengthening  and 
development, and a technical background in project management in the infrastructure sector. 
Experience  in  working  in  the  Pacific,  particularly  the  North  Pacific,  will  be  important.  The 
specialist  will  provide  leadership  in  establishing  and  strengthening  the  support  system  for 
improved  infrastructure  implementation  and  management.  The  specialist  will  also  play  a 
mentoring role in key project and program management issues, including risk assessment and 
mitigation; management of data and documentation; assessing project management capacity; 
and designing, delivering, and coordinating technical training. 
 
4.  The specialist will ensure timely delivery of outputs. The specialist will also prepare and 
submit necessary reports and conduct briefings and meetings with ADB staff, local counterparts 
and partners, and other stakeholders as needed. The specialist will have good negotiating skills 
and excellent relationship management skills. Specific tasks include: 
(i)  establishing a steering committee comprising leaders and change champions 
within DTCI and state utilities;  
(ii)  undertaking  an  in-depth  institutional  and  organizational  assessment  of  the 
systems, processes, and human resources of DTCI (including whether staff have 
the necessary qualifications to perform their responsibilities, and whether staff 
recruitment  and  promotion  processes  are  adequate),  taking  into  account  its 
readiness  to  change  and  the  motivating  forces  supporting  institutional 
strengthening, within the context of the expected outcomes of the Infrastructure 
Development Plan and the DTCI institutional road map;1   
                                                
1  The assessment will take into account and build upon the capacity assessments already undertaken, including that 
under ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Governance and Capacity Development Initiative (Phase 2). Manila 
(TA 7277-REG). It will encompass systems, processes, and human resources. The assessment will include (i) 
legal and regulatory frameworks, (ii) agency mandates, (iii) division of roles and responsibilities, (iv) linkage 
between mandates and/or performance targets and available human and financial resources, and (v) incentive 
systems. It will also assess possible change champions within DTCI. The TA will review transparency and

(xxvi)  designing and implementing a document management system and management 
information system for DTCI;  
(xxvii)  designing and obtaining approval for the contracts procedures manual, with the 
support of change agents across the network;  
(xxviii) implementing  procedures  laid  out  in  the  contracts  procedures  manual  within 
DTCI; and 
(xxix)  assessing the need for and implementing additional procedures manuals, as 
required. 
 
5.  The specialist will prepare the following reports: 
(i)  an inception report after 3 months, covering (a) confirmation of the overall TA 
rationale and design, (b) recommended adjustments to the terms of reference 
and timing of long-term specialists' deployment, (c) a schedule of inputs from 
short-term specialists for the following 33 months of the TA, and (d) a detailed TA 
implementation schedule; 
(ii)  monthly progress reports; 
(iii)  a draft TA completion report; and 
(iv)  a final TA completion report incorporating comments from ADB and the national 
and state governments. 
 
2.  Infrastructure Management Specialist (international, 5 person-months 
intermittent over 24 months) 
      
6.  The specialist will design and deliver specific technical training programs identified by 
the institutional strengthening and development specialist. This will include (i) an introduction to 
infrastructure  design,  (ii)  project  management,  (iii)  asset  management,  (iv) financial 
management,  (v)  procurement,  (vi)  contract  administration,  (vii)  risk  management,  (viii)  an 
overview  of  the  impact  of  climate  change  and  Clean  Development  Mechanism  on  project 
design, and (ix) other relevant areas. 
 
3.  Other Experts (international, 3 person-months; national, 12 person-months; 
intermittent) 
 
7.   The TA will require short-term consultants with capacity development expertise. Specific 
consulting requirements will be defined based on the detailed capacity assessment of all DTCI 
staff.
